title: Great App!
comment: This app is great. It imports/exports opml files for feed backups. I use that feature to keep my feeds synchronised with RSSOwl on my desktop. The only thing I find lacking is the ability to put feeds in sperate folders or tags to make browsing feeds of certain subjects easier. I might be overlooking something though, thus the 4 stars for a feature I can't find and need. Don't let this discourage you from using this app though. It is open source. It is tiny. It has a ton of features for it's size.

title: Simple news reader
comment: RSS reader to substitute Google Reader

title: Not bad, very lean
comment: Nice rss reader. Needs very few permissions which I really like. Swipe gestures are a bit clumsy. Font for overview not resizable. Other than that just what I need.

title: Excellent tiny rss apps.
comment: Tiny apps but work as expected.

title: Fast, efficient and no ads
comment: Can't get any better than this. Has opml import/export. The black theme is easy on Oled displays. Nice app

title: Great

title: Simple text rss
comment: I wanted a simple text rss reader.  This is perfect for what I wanted. Works fast,  good settings/ options,  and clicking an article takes me right to the website.

title: It's no Google Reader, but I like it.
comment: While panicking about what to do with my blog feeds, I stumbled upon this. I'm so glad I did because it's so simple and streamlined and easy to use. Thanks!

title: Just about excellent!
comment: This is just about exactly what I've been looking for in an RSS reader, and one that will make a fine basic replacement for Google Reader when it goes to that great big server farm in the sky.  It's simple, small, lightweight and seems to work well with the 40 feeds I imported from Opera.  The only down side I've found so far is the feed entry titles are a little small; font size can be adjusted but it only affects the text of the entry, not the title in the feed list.  Also, it lacks an easy and direct way to open the article in a browser.  You must go through the hassle of copying the link to the clipboard and manually pasting it into the browser.
Works well just what I needed simple& easy to use.
The UI lets it down a little bit. Good, though.

title: Great! Almost as Google Reader but on black background.

title: Great!
comment: I've been on an endless search for the perfect feed reader. This one is very easy to use and completely plain, which is what I wanted. My only suggestion would be to incorporate better theming options. I'd like to adjust the spacing between entries.

title: Will not refresh feeds!
comment: Site has new content, but this app WILL NOT refresh the feed. Tried multiple times, even created a new duplicate feed... no refresh. UNINSTALLED!

title: The best possible RSS reader
comment: No complaints. It does each of the things that the other readers I have tried failed to do.  Clean interface. Easy to use. Loads any rss url, even obscure ones that would not show up in search results.  Allows full control over when feeds update. The developer provided helpful answers to my questions.

title: An excellent offline RSS reader on my Nexus 7.
comment: A solid, simple, lightweight reader. The only feature I miss compared with my desktop reader is the ability to group feeds in folders. Thanks are due to the author.  This is an open source program and there are similar apps based on it. If you have one of these installed, as I had, uninstall it first or you get a 'duplicate' error.  This is not a web-based reader like Google reader, but you can import your feeds as an OPML file.

title: Best of the best
comment: This app works beautifully. Simple. I have set it to download blogs via rss.
Does what it says. Very useful app and its ad-free.

title: The missing link
comment: A plain, clean UI for reading, with local caching and OPML I/O. Now I just need an RSS->RSS feed merge resyndicator.

title: It works, no ads
comment: If you gonna import your feeds from Google Reader - open Reader in web browser in desktop mode, click Settings icon on the upper-right, select Export, download and unzip the resulting file, copy file subscriptions.xml to the root of your SD card, open Sparse RSS, click Menu->Import OPML, select subscriptions.xml, and you're done!

title: Exzellenter Ersatz für Google Reader
comment: Ich hätte nicht gedacht, dass ich so schnell einen exzellenten Ersatz für den Google Reader finde, der leider zur Jahresmitte 2013 eingestellt wird.  Schick aber simpel, schnell, funktional, durchdacht, einfach prima! Passt optisch auch gut zu Android 4.x. Vielen Dank an den Autor :-) Defy@4.1.2

title: I've found my Google Reader replacement
comment: This is just the rss reader I needed. Surprisingly, I like the Sparse rss interface better than the interface of Google Reader - and I appreciate the customization options. Thanks a bunch, Stefan!

title: bye
comment: checking out different RSS apps. most immediately ask permission to access your account. you say yes...bingo! you're ready to roll and take the app for a test drive. not this app. I fiddled with the settings for a minute and thought y am I doing all the work? I'm off to the next RSS app to try out

title: Great lightweight RSS reader
comment: Does just what I need without extra cruft. Maybe some individual feed retention options would be a nice addition, but it still deserves 5 stars.

title: Simple and effective
comment: Lightweight and does what I need. Perfect.

title: Light & Simple W/Notification
comment: I tested several rss apps and only this app met my expectations. It does not consume to much power or memory. The ability to turn off pictures is a huge plus for my needs. The only thing I would suggest is a is a DND feature for the notifications.

title: Superfast and lightweight
comment: This app maybe doesn't have the highest rating when it comes to RSS readers but does everything I need out of a reader very faster and simpler than any other app I tried. Most feed readers are overbloated in my opinion

title: the holy grail of feed readers

title: da Only
comment: P r o s >>> opml import + can store images for offline view + humble    C o n s >>> no search in feeds - no auto label -no alphabetic sorting -sometimes not storing images      DA BEST so far

title: Good RSS reader and no BS
comment: This is exactly what I was looking for:  a simple RSS reader that does its job well and doesn't show ads or try to harvest my personal information or location.  It works well and I can read the feeds inside the app or open them in a browser, and if there is multimedia content I can download it from inside the app.  It's really easy to set it up so it downloads and updates how you prefer and how it shows you read or unread content and so on.  Everything works how I expected.  I tried quite a few RSS readers and this is easily the best.

title: Yay!
comment: One word: awesome!

title: RSSOwl for mobile
comment: If you love RSSOwl for Windows then Sparse rss is your mobile RSS reader. Make sure you pick the original by Stefan Handschuh and not a fork that's out there.

title: Very good, but invasive
comment: Thanks for publishing a free, no nonsense RSS reader for Android. True to its name, Sparse rss is free, small, fast enough, ad-free, largely non-invasive, and easy to use; and it offers only essential functionality. However, the app always caches an instance of itself on boot. I can't find a way to stop it doing so, even with root tools. That is not good.
Great reader

title: A very clean & Light app
comment: FEATURES      - The 4x2 widget can display 10 feeds so you just unlock the screen and have the latest news right there   - It has an option to manually refresh some feeds so important feeds auto-update on mobile network while others      you can always manually refresh over wi-fi or mobile network.    - The background of the widget can be customized using the RGB slider   - Users can swipe left-right to navigate between the feeds or use left-right arrow buttons   - Font size & auto update interval is user defined  IMPROVEMENTS     - Fetching the entire article from the news feed, currently Taptu & full sparse rss do this job well but are ad supported

title: Perfect

title: Very Lightweight, but Doesn't Always Work
comment: I like that Sparse RSS is...sparse. There's no fluff here. Just add your feed URL and that's that. However, I added 7 feed URLs manually, but only 3 would update. They all pulled in the correct title from the web so I know the URLs were valid. But 4 of the feeds just sat at 0 posts despite manual refreshing. For the 3 that load, the interface is uncluttered and easy to read. I don't like that it didn't pull the entire article (I know that is set by the feed but there are ways around it).
Great, how about making the widget transparent? :-)
